SHORT_DESCR.P: The Veldhorst lab at TU Delft studies spin qubits that operate at temperature range from <1K, to <100mk, to <10mK. Currently the Veldhorst lab set up consists of three fridges, but an expansion of the set-up is required.

The Veldhorst lab operates in a way that devices and components can be easily switched from one setup to another setup. As such, it is important for the new fridge to be identical to the existing setups and fridges. In addition, the lines and filters have been optimized and tailored. Furthermore, the lab has joint experiments with other researchers at Delft, resulting in a significant amount of compatible setups. Deviating from this would result in a significant delay of the research and may also prevent further progress. In addition, the developments of these components are made for the existing setups and developing new components and operating under different circumstances will impact the viability of comparing research results due to differences in performance.

The Veldhorst lab at TU Delft studies spin qubits that operate at temperature range from <1K, to <100mk, to <10mK. Currently the Veldhorst lab set up consists of three fridges, but an expansion of the set-up is required.

The Veldhorst lab operates in a way that devices and components can be easily switched from one setup to another setup. As such, it is important for the new fridge to be identical to the existing setups and fridges. In addition, the lines and filters have been optimized and tailored. Furthermore, the lab has joint experiments with other researchers at Delft, resulting in a significant amount of compatible setups. Deviating from this would result in a significant delay of the research and may also prevent further progress. In addition, the developments of these components are made for the existing setups and developing new components and operating under different circumstances will impact the viability of comparing research results due to differences in performance.

D_JUSTIFICATION.P: The Veldhorst lab studies spin qubits that operate at low temperatures. Experiments range from <1K, to <100mk, to <10mK, and at all of these temperature ranges good time stability is required to allow for extensive measurements that can last for months. Currently the Veldhorst lab set up consists of three Bluefors fridges, but an expansion of the set-up is required (with identical specifications).

The Veldhorst lab operates in a way that devices and components can be easily switched from one setup to another setup. Many components (pcb’s, filters) are homemade and optimized for the experiments. As such, it is important for the new fridge to be compatible with the existing setups and fridges. In particular, there have been significant time and cost investments in the design of a cold finger (several iterations have been optimized in a time span of several years). In addition, the lines and filters have been optimized and tailored. Furthermore, the lab has joint experiments with other researchers at Delft, resulting in a significant amount of compatible setups. Deviating from this would result in a significant delay of the research and may also prevent further progress. In addition, the developments of these components are made for the existing setups and developing new components and operating under different circumstances will impact the viability of comparing research results due to differences in performance.

In addition to the above, it is important to have a flexibility to switch between components of a fridge. For example, to be able to change the magnets between fridges, or the cold fingers, or the filters, without overhead or making compromises to the experiment.
In order to continue and expand the current capabilities, it is insurmountable to purchase another Bluefors dilution refrigerator.
